contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word "house" represents family. Alternate translation: "Both I and my family" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: Both I and my father's house

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word "name" represents Yahweh himself. Alternate translation: "where I have chosen to dwell" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: where I have chosen to make my name remain

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "hand" represents strength or power. Together, these two phrases form a doublet that emphasizes the intensity of Yahweh's power. Alternate translation: "by your great power and by your mighty strength" or "by your very powerful strength" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.glQuote: by your great power and by your strong hand

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "name" represents Yahweh himself. Alternate translation: "who delight to honor you" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: who delight to honor your name

contextId.occurrenceNote: God's "good hand" represents his "favor." Alternate translation: "God's favor was upon me" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: the good hand of God was on me

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Nehemiah's "heart" refers to his thoughts and will. Alternate translation: "had inspired me" or "had led me" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: had put into my heart

contextId.occurrenceNote: God's "good hand" represents his "favor." Alternate translation: "my God's favor was upon me" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: the good hand of my God was on me

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "Jerusalem" refers to the people who live there. Alternate translation: "against the people of Jerusalem" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: against Jerusalem

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the number 10 is used to represent "many." Alternate translation: "spoke to us many times" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: spoke to us ten times

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to someone blowing a trumpet. Alternate translation: "someone blowing a trumpet" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: the trumpet sound

contextId.occurrenceNote: It is the point in time that the sun rises that is "dawn." Here the sun rising is spoken of as if the "dawn" rose. Alternate translation: "the rising of the sun" or "dawn" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: the rising of the dawn

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means he had the letter in his possession, but he did not necessarily carry it in his hand at all times. Alternate translation: "in his possession" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: in his hand

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the "heart" refers to the "mind," that is, to one's desires and thoughts. Alternate translation: "for within your mind you invented them" or "for you have made this up in your own imagination" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: for within your heart you invented them

contextId.occurrenceNote: The nobles sent messengers to bring these letters to Tobiah. Alternate translation: "sent many messengers with letters" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: sent many letters

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Nehemiah's "heart" refers to his thoughts and will. See how you translated this in [Nehemiah 2:12](../02/12.md). Alternate translation: "inspired me" or "led me" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: put into my heart

contextId.occurrenceNote: "whom Nebuchadnezzar, ruler of Babylon, took away from their home country." The army of Babylon did this under the command of Nebuchadnezzar. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: whom Nebuchadnezzar the king of Babylon took into exile

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "house" is a metonym for family. Alternate translation: "from the family of Jeshua" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: of the house of Jeshua

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "name" represents a reputation. Alternate translation: "you made yourself famous and even now people still remember" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: you made a name for yourself which stands to this day

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "hand" represents power or control. Alternate translation: "you allowed their enemies to defeat them and cause them to suffer" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: you gave them into the hand of their enemies, who made them suffer

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "hand" represents power or control. Alternate translation: "you sent people to stop their enemies from harming them" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: you sent them rescuers who rescued them out of the hand of their enemies

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "hand" represents power or control. Alternate translation: "you abandoned them and allow their enemies to defeat them" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: you abandoned them to the hand of their enemies

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh himself is spoken of as if he were the decrees themselves. Alternate translation: "you even though you give life to everyone who obeys your decrees" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: your decrees which give life to anyone who obeys them

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "hand" represents power or control. See how you translated these words in [Nehemiah 9:27](../09/27.md). Alternate translation: "you allowed the neighboring peoples to defeat them" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: you gave them into the hand of the neighboring peoples

contextId.occurrenceNote: "The joy of Jerusalem" here is a metonym for "the sound that the people of Jerusalem made." This can be translated in active form. Alternate translation: "people far away from Jerusalem could hear the sound that the people of Jerusalem made as they celebrated" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.glQuote: So the joy of Jerusalem could be heard far away

contextId.occurrenceNote: The name of the land is a metonym for the people of the land. This is probably a generalization. Alternate translation: "all the people who lived in Judah" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])
contextId.glQuote: all Judah

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "winepresses" is a metonym for the grapes that were in the winepresses. The people were walking on grapes to get the juice out of them to make wine. Alternate translation: "walking on grapes in winepresses" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: treading winepresses

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "hands" is a metonym for forceful action. Alternate translation: "I will send you away by force!" or "I will remove you by force!" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: I will lay hands on you!
